Idiom (Aranese): Èster coma un burro en un jardim
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed simile, clause with prepositional complement
Figurative Meaning: To be completely out of place or clueless in a situation
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: To not belong or understand what's going on
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to rural-urban divide in Aran Valley; burros (donkeys) seen as rustic
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Aranese): ˈɛste ˈkumə un ˈburʊ en un ʒaɾˈdim
First Example Sentence: Quan parlèrem de tecnologia, ère coma un burro en un jardim.
Second Example Sentence: Eth hilh a arribat a classa naua e s’a trapat coma un burro en un jardim.
Third Example Sentence: En aqueth sopar sofisticat, me sentic coma un burro en un jardim.

Idiom (Aranese): Cantar coma un gal sus eth teulat
Figurative Meaning: To boast loudly and publicly, often without reason
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: To show off or brag loudly
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Symbolic of traditional village life; roosters crowing visibly from rooftops
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Aranese): kanˈtaɾ ˈkumə un ˈɡal sus et tewˈlat
First Example Sentence: Despuish guanhar, comencèc a cantar coma un gal sus eth teulat.
Second Example Sentence: Tot eth temps ei a cantar coma un gal sus eth teulat.
Third Example Sentence: Quan a hèt quicòm ben, non pòt pas evitar de cantar coma un gal sus eth teulat.

Idiom (Aranese): Aué non ei eth dia deth ton sèt
Figurative Meaning: This is not your lucky day; things aren't going your way
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Things aren’t going well for you today
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reference to Saint’s day and local beliefs around fate and luck
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Aranese): awˈe noˈne et ˈdiə det ˈtɔn sɛt
First Example Sentence: Perdèc eth bus, oblidéc eth trabalh... aué non ei eth dia deth ton sèt!
Second Example Sentence: Se ves que non i a escandilh: aué non ei eth dia deth ton sèt.
Third Example Sentence: Encara qu’estries, tot va mal: aué non ei eth dia deth ton sèt.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Reflexive verb phrase with directional preposition
Figurative Meaning: To go completely wrong or downhill
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: To fall apart or get ruined
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: References traditional Aranese metaphor about decay or disorder
First Example Sentence: Des d’eth cambiament de cap, tot s’ei anat tà pèdes de can.
Second Example Sentence: Eth projècte, sense guida, se’n va tà pèdes de can.
Third Example Sentence: Quan arriben es errors, tot se’n va tà pèdes de can.

Idiom (Aranese): Hèr es uelhs grossi coma plats
Figurative Meaning: To be very surprised or shocked
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Visual metaphor rooted in expressive face reactions in rural culture
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Aranese): eɾ es ˈweʎs ˈɡɾosi ˈkumə ˈplats
First Example Sentence: Quan vedec eth prètz, hec es uelhs grossi coma plats.
Second Example Sentence: M’a contat ua istòria e jo hec es uelhs grossi coma plats.
Third Example Sentence: Eth mainatge hec es uelhs grossi coma plats quan arribèc eth mag.

Idiom (Aranese): Dobrir eth pèish abans de pescalo
Figurative Meaning: To assume success before achieving it
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: To count your chickens before they hatch
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional fishing culture; warning against early assumptions
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Aranese): duˈβɾiɾ et ˈpɛʃ aˈβans de pəsˈkaɫu
First Example Sentence: Parlèc dera victòria abans d'arribar: dobric eth pèish abans de pescalo.
Second Example Sentence: Encara qu’an planificat tot, dobrissen eth pèish abans de pescalo.
Third Example Sentence: Non dobres eth pèish abans de pescalo, jamès sap çò que pòt passar.

Idiom (Aranese): Es causes van a pas de formiga
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Things are moving at a snail’s pace
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws from observation of ants’ slow but steady pace
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Aranese): es ˈkawzəs βan a pas de fuɾˈmiɣə
First Example Sentence: Eth projècte avança, mès a pas de formiga.
Second Example Sentence: Tot sembla lent... es causes van a pas de formiga.
Third Example Sentence: A l’ajuntament, tot se hè a pas de formiga.

Idiom (Aranese): Non saber a on picar eth cap
Figurative Meaning: To be overwhelmed or not know what to do
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Head represents control; common image of stress in Pyrenean speech
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Aranese): non saˈβeɾ a un piˈkaɾ et ˈkap
First Example Sentence: Damnat! Non sabi a on picar eth cap.
Second Example Sentence: Tant de problèmas qu’eth pair non sabie a on picar eth cap.
Third Example Sentence: Quan arriben es factures, toti non saben a on picar eth cap.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Transitive verb phrase with prepositional complement
Figurative Meaning: To be struck speechless or stunned by beauty
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Aranese poetic image, love-struck imagery
First Example Sentence: Quan la vedec, perdic era lengua enes uelhs.
Second Example Sentence: Era vista deth paisatge me hèc pèrder era lengua enes uelhs.
Third Example Sentence: Es sòns uelhs... e jo, sense paraules: perdic era lengua enes uelhs.

Second Example Sentence: Trobam-se cada serada a hèr-la petar.
Third Example Sentence: Non i a res de melhor qu’a hèr-la petar damb amics.
